loans.name: Rubelyn

texts.en:
This is Rubelyn, 33, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Rosalino, a vendor.  They have two children. Rubelyn, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Rubelyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php 13,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Rubelyn hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
This is Adelaida, 54, resident of Manila, the Philippines. She is married to Ricardo, her business partner, they have four children. Adeliada, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Adelaida operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Adelaida hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
This is Lea, 33, resident of Manila, the Philippines. She is married to Renato, her business partner, and they have one child. Lea, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Lea operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 100 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Lea hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is married with two school-going children. They live in a house, which they own.  It has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past ten years, she has operated a second hand clothes-selling business; selling from door to door to her neighbours. Judith cites the high cost of transportation as her major challenge in the business as she move from door to door. She dreams of establishing a boutique shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bales of clothes to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Bonifacia

texts.en:
Bonifacia is a married with two children. She is 50 years old and lives in Pantaon, Ozamis City, the Philippines. Bonifacia owns and operates a plot of farm land, planting bananas to earn a living. She has been in this business for ten years and earns PHP 6,000 each month. She has requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to purchase farm chemicals. 

Bonifacia is a new member of Kiva's partner, GDMPC. Bonifacia's aim is to save her profit in order to buy a car.

loans.use: to purchase farm chemicals to improve her banana farm.

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en: Narantuya is a 51-year-old widow who lives with her parents and a son in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her son is employed. She started a garment retail business in 2004, based on her prior work experience at a local trade center. She purchases supplies from a wholesaler in China and sells them at a good price to her customers. She has made many regular customers at the center. She is responsible for the business and has essential business knowledge. Narantuya is a gentle and hardworking woman who says, "I would like to expand the business by purchasing the garment supplies in large quantities and increasing the current assets." The total amount she is requesting is 1,500,000 MNT to buy more garment supplies.

loans.use: To buy more garment supplies

loans.name: Julian Group

texts.en:
Mona is the featured borrower for Julian's group. She got together with her other group members to take this Al Majmoua loan because they have always been neighbors and friends. She sells souvenirs, gifts, and perfumes in order to help her husband make their living.

Mona is a hard-working woman who seeks perfection in her business to keep her customers satisfied. With her good reputation, her business is expanding more and more through the new customers she's accepting and expecting in the future. Mona does well in her business because she has to make sure that it will be developed in a special professional way to provide her child a healthy and lovely future.

Mona is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to expand her business capital by increasing her stocks of perfume brands, souvenirs, and gadgets in order to provide her customers with a wide variety of choices for different occasions. She hopes to expand her business more and more in the future because she loves what she is doing and she is sure that as long she's working right her business will improve her family's social and financial situation.

loans.use: to expand her business capital by increasing her stocks of perfume brands, souvenirs, and gadgets

loans.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida is from Dona Consuelo, Ozamis City. She is 46 years old and married with four children. To earn a living, Aida manages a retail business, where she sells food and used products. Aida has been in her business for 7 years and earns PHP 9,000 a month from these activities. In 2005, Aida joined GDMPC. She is requesting a loan of PHP 11,600, which she will use to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar, and coffee. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar, and coffee

loans.name: Sari Ayu Group

texts.en:
With five members left, the Sari Ayu group continues to borrow from MUK to expand its business. Three of their friends became successful and became motivation for them. They want success and to improve their families' welfare. 

The new head of the group is Ni Luh. Ni Luh has two children. The first child is in junior high school and the second is a toddler. Ni Luh is the wife of a government official in her village. Her husband is very supportive of her efforts since they have proven to improve the welfare of their family.

Ni Luh is using the loan to buy a sow worth 1,500,000 IDR. She already has two sows. Cages have been prepared to accommodate the piglets to be born. She has a plan to sell piglets.
 
Ni Luh hopes her efforts will be as successful as those of her three friends.

loans.use: to purchase a sow.

loans.name: Ernesto

texts.en: Ernesto is a 36-year-old fisherman from Bien Unido, Bohol. He is married and has a 12-year-old child. He has been involved in fishing for 10 years. He earns 6000 PHP per month from fishing. He also sells crabs to his community. He plans to use his loan to purchase fishing nets and to repair his fishing boat. Ernesto hopes for his income to improve so he can start repairing their house.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets and repair his fishing boat

loans.name: Stela

texts.en: Stela is 30 years old and lives in Gata Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is now married with 1 child. Stela used her last loan to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Her business has grown and become successful. She's now taking a new loan to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Positively, she hopes to be able to continue to grow her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise

loans.name: Prudencia

texts.en:
Prudencia is 57 years old and is from Panta-on, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She is married and blessed with two children. 

Prudencia is working as baker to help the family to earn a living. She has been in this business for 15 years and earns about 5,000 PHP per month.

In 2007, Prudencia joined GDMPC. She requested a loan in the amount of 4,730 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

Prudencia plans that the income generated from her loan will be invested back into the business and ultimately hopes to expand the size of the business.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Metrine

texts.en:
Metrine is married with three school-going children. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rental bills, and school fees.

Metrine operates a business making dumplings and samosas to sell from her home to her neighbours. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding to a large business in the future. 

With the KES 10,000 she is requesting, she wants to purchase wheat flour, cooking fat and oil, and charcoal for cooking. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, cooking fat and oil, and charcoal.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita is married and has three children. Juanita is 42 years old and lives in the Philippines. 

Juanita is operating a motorcycle transport business to earn a living. She's been doing this for six years and every month she earns 7,300 PHP from this work. 

She has requested a loan of 8,500 PHP to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. 

In 2009, Juanita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. In the future, Juanita hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in the business.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a resident and a farmer in the Kisii area of South Rift, Kenya. He is 56 and a father of seven children between 23 and 10 years.

He has been in farming for 10 successive years and currently sells his products, which are mainly kale, bananas and milk, to the local market.

Francis has requested a loan of 26,000 KES from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. He says this will boost his farming income and he intends to use the income to further venture into the poultry business as well. He adds that the milk will also supplement family meals.

Francis says the unpredictability of rains is the main challenge with dry spells and flash floods being too common. He adds that the latter usually damages crops in the field.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is from Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old, married, and has three children. 

To make a living, Evangeline runs a general store, selling a variety of food and household products to members of the local community. Evangeline has been in her business for 2 years and earns PHP 3,000 a month from these activities.

Evangeline is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000, which she will use to purchase new items to expand her product offering. In 2011, Evangeline joined GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en: Esterlita is a food vendor from Trinidad, Bohol. She sells rice cakes, peanut brittle, and other local delicacies. She earns 4000 PHP per month from food vending. She also helps her husband manage their rice farm. Esterlita works hard to provide for their needs and sustain her children's education. She plans to use her loan to purchase farm fertilizers and ingredients such as flour, sugar, margarine, and cooking oil. Esterlita hopes for their businesses to grow and for her children to finish college and have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase farm fertilizers and ingredients such as flour, sugar, margarine, and cooking oil

loans.name: Ramon

texts.es:
El Sr. Ramon de 25 años de edad,  tiene un Taller de moto en la ciudad de Caaguazú, es soltero  y tiene una hija de 1 año y 7 meses de edad.
El Sr. Ramon empezó a trabajar desde niño,  tenía 8 años aproximadamente cuando empezó como secretario de un taller mecánico aprendiendo el oficio de mecánico. Hace 5 años aproximadamente decidió independizarse y armo poco a poco su propio taller para motos.  Con el correr de los años fue afianzándose y así ir creciendo.  Con las ganancias del negocio siempre mantuvo el hogar y logra con mucho esfuerzo quitar adelante a su familia.
El sr. Ramon utilizaría el crédito que solicita para agrandar el taller ya que le gustaría ofrecer otros servicios como el de lavadero, y  así darle a su clientela un servicio más completo.
texts.en:
Ramon is 25 years old. He has a motorcycle workshop in the city of Caaguazú. He is single and has one daughter who is a year and seven months old. 

Ramon started working when he was a boy. He was about 8 years old when he started as an assistant in a mechanic's workshop, learning the mechanic's trade. About 5 years ago, he decided to work independently, and little by little he set up his own motorcycle workshop. Over the course of the years, he continued to strengthen and expand his business. With the earnings from the business, he always maintained his home, and with great effort he has succeeded in helping his family get ahead. 

Ramon will use the loan he is requesting to expand his workshop, since he would like to offer more services, such as washing, so that he can give his customers more complete service.

loans.use: to expand his repair workshop.

loans.name: Jason

texts.en:
Jason is a multicab driver living in the town of Trinidad, Bohol with his family. He earns 6000 PHP per month transporting people around his community. Jason also sells bananas and cassava. He works hard to support his family of a wife and one child. He plans to start raising hogs to help augment his income.

Jason requested this loan to purchase spare parts and more bananas to sell. He hopes to elevate his family's standard of living and save for his child's education.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and more bananas to sell.

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita is fifty-one years old, living in Miligan, Molave, Zamoboanga Del sur. She is married with three children who are already adults.  Florita has been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for almost four years.  She has been pig fattening for mamy years to provide the financial need of her family.  

Florita has requested a loan amount of PHP 11,000 to purchase more feed for her hog fattening.  Florita, hopes thats someday she can earn more than she needs to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase more feed to fatten her pigs.

loans.name: Jhaquilou

texts.en: Jhaquilou is 22 years old and is a married woman with a 3-year-old child. Her husband is a fisherman. Jhaquilo has had a sari-sari store (general store) business for 5 years. She sells items like coffee, diapers, soft drinks, and canned goods. She is able to help provide for her family's basic needs with her income. Jhaquilou wants to increase her income so she can start saving for her child's education. She has requested a loan to buy more items to sell such as rice, soft drinks, and canned goods. This will help increase her sales and profitability.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell such as rice, soft drinks, and canned goods

loans.name: Jacinto

texts.en:
Jacinto is a farmer from Trinidad, Bohol. He is 49 years old, married and has a 21-year-old child. 

Jacinto tills his own land and grows rice crops to sell. He earns 8,000 PHP per month doing this farming. He works hard to improve his income and provide his family a more stable living. He plans to use this loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. 

Jacinto hopes to achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Tulay Group

texts.en:
Mayssam is the featured borrower for Tulay's group. She got together with her other group members to take this Al Majmoua loan because they have always been neighbors and friends. 

She sells home detergents and cleaning products at home in order to help her husband in making their living. Mayssam is a hard working woman who seeks perfection in her business to keep her customers satisfied. With her good reputation, her business is expanding more and more. Although she works at home, most of her customers like to come and buy from her and enjoy visiting her a lot.

Mayssam does well in her business. She is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to expand her business capital with new detergents and cleaning products with special prices.
 
She is working to expand her business more and more in the future, and she hopes to open a wholesale shop in the future.

Mayssam will also invest part of her loan in fixing her plumbing to keep her house a healthy living place.

loans.use: To increase her business capital with new detergents and cleaning products with special prices.

loans.name: Imad

texts.en: Imad is a 40-year-old man. He’s married and lives with his wife and four children. Because he’s the one responsible for his family, Imad works nonstop to be able to offer them a suitable life. He has owned a scrap shop since 2009. His job consists of buying and reselling used supplies and equipment. Today, he intends to take a loan from Kiva Partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional products for his shop. This will boost his sales, thus increasing his profits. In the future, he plans to expand his business and better support his family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products for his shop

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
This is Nancy, 40, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Agapito, her business partner, and is a mother to her two children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Nancy operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Nancy hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a farmer in Kitale, Western Kenya, where she lives with her husband and their four children who are between the ages of three and twenty years. Her farm primarily produces maize, which the family sells to earn income to meet their other needs. Other farm produce is produced in small quantities and consumed within the family.

Hellen has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy poultry birds. She wants to venture into poultry farming in order to exploit the ready market existing in the area. She believes the business will grow and enable her expand the salon business she runs in addition to farming.

Hellen sees the unreliable nature of farmhands and the poor road network as the major challenges she faces in her business.

loans.use: to buy poultry birds

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en: Mohammad is a 55-year-old Lebanese man. He’s married, living with his wife and only child, who is still attending school. In order to pay his child’s school fees and enhance his family’s way of living, Mohammad strives to work really hard. He has his own secondhand store, and he has many years of experience in this domain. He’s now looking to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase his inventory of products and develop his work. He notes that this Kiva loan will increase his sales and therefore his revenues. In the future, he plans to open other branches of his business as soon as possible.

loans.use: to increase his inventory of products

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en:
This is Josefa, 48, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is a single parent of three children. She, together with her children, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Josefa operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Josefa hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Magdalina

texts.en: Magdalina is from Tabid, Ozamis City. She is 37 years old, married, and has 3 children. To make a living, Magdalina makes and sells charcoal. She has been in her business for 9 years and earns PHP 4,000 per month from these activities. In 2010, Magdalina joined GDMPC. She is requesting a loan of PHP 5,800, which she will use to purchase coconut shells for making charcoal. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase coconut shells to make charcoal

loans.name: Ibonne

texts.en:
Ibonne is 24 years old and married. She has a 1-month-old baby. Her husband is a fisherman. 

Ibonne is also involved in fishing. She helps her husband prepare his fishing materials. She also sells his catch at the market and makes dried fish to sell. 

Ibonne wants to be able to help provide for her family's basic needs. She applied for this loan to purchase a fishing boat. This will help Ibonne and her family with their fishing business.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat.

loans.name: Rosalita

texts.en:
Rosalita is 69 years old and widowed with 12 children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Rosalita has a nipa (woven palm wood ) business in the Philippines. Rosalita requested a 19,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional stock of nipa to sell.

Rosalita has been in this business for 14 years. In the future, Rosalita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of nipa (woven palm wood) to sell.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is 23 years old and married.

Stella works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock for her business.

Stella has borrowed and repaid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for two years and also earns an income from buying and selling rice.

Stella aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her business.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a 41-year-old Lebanese married man. He lives with his wife and three children, who are still attending school. He strives to work really hard in order to improve his family’s way of living. Hassan has been working on his own trucks since 18 years. He’s well known for his good work and reputation as well. He also visits his customers wherever they are if needed. Today, he has the intention to borrow a loan from Kiva Partner Ameen s.a.l. to fix his truck’s engine in order to carry on his work in a proper way and nonstop without facing problems. In the future, he plans to take more Kiva loans, better develop his work and hire someone to work with him.

loans.use: to fix his truck’s engine

loans.name: Ma. Anabelle

texts.en:
Ma. Anabelle is a 37-year-old married woman with 3 school-aged children. Her husband is a farmer.

Ma. Anabelle owns and manages a sari-sari store business in Trinidad, Bohol. She sells snack foods, shampoo, soap, and other various items. She earns 4,000 PHP per month with her business. She works hard to improve her income to support her family. She has requested a loan to purchase additional items to sell such as snack foods, spices and canned goods. This will help increase her sales and business profitability.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell such as snack foods, spices and canned goods

loans.name: Rufina

texts.en:
Rufina is 49 years old and lives in Mitazan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is married with two children. 

Rufina has a piggery and also sells pigs. She has had this business for 2 years. She requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase feeds for her pig business. Rufina has been a member of PMPC for 6 years. In the future, Rufina hopes that his business will grow for the future of her children.

loans.use: to purchase feeds for her pig business

loans.name: Ma. Lina

texts.en:
Ma. Lina is a fish seller. She also helps her husband, who is a fisherman, prepare his fish nets, hooks and gear. Ma. Lina works hard to help sustain her family. She has 3 school-aged children that she hopes will be able to go to college in the future.

Ma. Lina is requesting a loan to purchase fish nets and more fish and crabs to sell. She hopes for her business to grow and for her family to have a more stable living.

loans.use: to purchase fish nets and more fish and crabs to sell

loans.name: Joena

texts.en:
Joena, 44, runs a sari-sari (local convenience) store in Bien Unido, Bohol. Joena is married with five children, ages 15 to 23. Her husband works as a seaweed gatherer.

Joena sells various items in her store such as shampoo, bath and detergent soap, canned goods, rice and powdered milk. Joena does her best to keep her customers loyal to her store. She wants to improve her income to help her husband provide for their needs and sustain their children's education. She requested this loan to buy more merchandise to sell such as rice, milk and toiletries. This will help increase Joena's sales and business profitability.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise to sell such as rice, milk and toiletries.

loans.name: Andrilita

texts.en:
This is Andrilita, 40, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Eddie, her business partner, and father to her eight children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Andrilita operates a photo shop business. She offers basic photo services to her community. She also sells cell phone accessories and picture frames for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional stocks of photo supplies and cell phone accessories to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Andrilita hopes to be able to expand her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of photo supplies and cell phone accessories needed in her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to increase her stock of soda, juice, mandazi, chapati, water and rice.

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en: Marlyn is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines. She works hard to support her family. Marlyn requested a PHP 23000 loan through NWTF to purchase fishing materials for her business, which she has operated for five years. In the future, Marlyn would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fishing materials for her business.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en: Mary Jane is married and has 11 children, She works hard to support her family with her business buying and selling fruit. She earns additional income  buying and selling seafood. Mary Jane wants to borrow PHP 20000 through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of fruit to sell. Mary Jane has been sustaining her business activities through her past 18 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of fruit to sell.

loans.name: Al Bader Group

texts.en:
Layla is the featured borrower for Al Bader's group. She got together with her other group members to take this Al Majmoua loan because they have always been neighbors and friends. 

Layla makes and sells Saj Bread, a special traditional Lebanese bread highly requested in her area. She also makes crochet (a handicraft in which yarn is looped into a patterned fabric with a hooked needle).

Layla is a hardworking woman who seeks perfection in her business to keep her customers satisfied. She helps her husband in making a living and covering their five children's expenses.

Her good reputation helped a lot in improving and expanding her business more and more.

Layla is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to buy a new improved dough-making machine, necessary to ease her business.

Layla is working hard on expanding her business, and she believes that although she is 49 years old, she can still expand her business and increase her capital.

loans.use: To buy a necessary dough-making machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizer and supplies.

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en: Marlene is 58 years old and lives in Lutao, Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She is married and has five children. Marlene has a hog-fattening business and earns approximately 5,000 PHP each month doing this work. She has requested a loan of 14,900 PHP to purchase feed for her hogs. Marlene has been a member of PMPC for six years. In the future, Marlene hopes to build a livestock farm.

loans.use: To purchase feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase dairy products such as yogurt, milk bags, and cartons of milk.

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
Teodora is a 57-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has been a dressmaker for quite a long time now. Teodora says she now has regular customers in her town. She earns 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) each month. Teodora works hard to support her family. Her husband is a fisherman.

Teodora has requested a loan to buy tailoring materials such as cloth, threads, zippers and needles. Teodora hopes for her business to grow.

loans.use: to buy tailoring materials such as cloth, threads, zippers and needles.

loans.name: Elvira Alfonsina

texts.es:
Elvira, tiene 50 años de edad, está casada desde hace 35 años tiene 6 hijos entre edades de 15 a 34 años, vive con su familia en San Pedro Sula.
Doña Elvira desde muy joven aprendió a costurar en maquina, trabajo un tiempo en la maquila y hace 15 años emprendió su propio negocio donde confecciona todo tipo de ropa, como uniformes, sabanas, cortinas, camisas, pantalones, short corto, etc. lo que el cliente solicite. Con este negocio ella apoya a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y la educación de sus hijos.
Esta solicitando un préstamo de 3,000.00 para comprar tela para elaborar buzos (uniforme de física de una escuela), es su tercer préstamo, los dos anteriores los ha invertido en el negocio también. Su meta es seguir trabajando para ayudar a sus hijos con el estudio y ayudar con los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
Elvira, 50, has been married for 35 years.  She has six children whose ages range between 15 and 35.  She lives with her family in San Pedro Sula.

Elvira learned to use a sewing machine when she was still quite young.  She worked in an assembly plant for a time and fifteen years ago started her own business manufacturing all types of clothes like uniforms, sheets, curtains, shirts, pants, shorts, etc., whatever the customer requests.  With this business she helps her husband with household expenses and with their children’s schooling costs.

She’s asking for a 3,000.00 loan to buy fabric to make sweatshirts (physical education uniform for a school).  This is her third loan; she invested the previous two in her business too.  Her goal is to continue working to support her children’s schooling and to help with household expenses.

loans.use: to buy fabric to manufacture school physical education uniforms.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is married with seven children. She is 42 years old and lives in the Philippines. Evelyn used her last loan to purchase equipment for copra. Her business has grown and become successful. Now, she's taking a new loan to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Positively, she hopes to be able to grow her business more.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Remegia Group

texts.en:
Remegia is 61 years old and lives in San Vicente, Sinacaban. Remegia is widowed with three children. 

To earn a living, Remegia has a business selling snacks. Remegia earns about 2,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) each month doing this type of work. Remegia has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional ingredients such as flour, sugar, oil, etc.

Remegia has been a member of PMPC for five months. In the future, Remegia would like to expand her business.

Remegia is the leader of a two-person group. Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has their own business.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients such as flour, sugar, oil, etc.

loans.name: Zarah Jane

texts.en:
Zarah Jane, age 36,  is married with 4 children who are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Zarah Jane has a restaurant business in the Philippines. Zarah Jane requested a PHP 10000 loan amount through NWTF to buy additional ingredients for her business.

Zarah Jane has been in this business for 5 years. In the future, Zarah Jane would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional ingredients for her business

loans.name: Paata

texts.en:
Paata is 44 years old. He lives in the Kareli District with his wife – Mzia. The family earns a living through an agricultural business. They have 2.5 hectares of land where tomatoes, cabbages, garlic and strawberries are grown. Paata sells harvested products to local greengrocery retailers. Total average monthly income of the family is 850 Laris. 

Paata has requested credit for financing seasonal agricultural works. He will rent a tractor for cultivation of the land. Also Paata will purchase fertilizers and drugs for treating the plants for parasites. Paata and Mzia will work hard on their plot during spring season. After properly completed seasonal works the family will get a better and greater harvest than in the last year. They will sell it through known distribution channels for a good price and get profit which will be used for renovation of family house in order to make it more comfortable.

loans.use: to rent a tractor and to purchase fertilizers and drugs to treat plants for parasites

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is a hardworking entrepreneur whose business is selling dried fish in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 30000 through NWTF to buy more fish for her dried fish business.

Teresita has been in this business for 14 years. Teresita earns additional income from fish vending.

Teresita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic is 44 years old and married with 6 children.

Marivic works hard to provide for her family. She runs a business buying and selling phone accessories in the Philippines and requested a PHP 25000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell.

Marivic has borrowed and paid 10 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the business buying and selling phone accessories for 5 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Marivic aspires to save enough money so she can send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock to sell

loans.name: Gerarda

texts.en:
Gerarda is 62 years old and widowed with six children.

Gerarda works hard to provide for her family. She runs a tailoring materials retail business in the Philippines and requested a 22,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell.

Gerarda has borrowed and repaid 21 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the tailoring materials retail business for 10 years and also earns an income from dressmaking.

Gerarda aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more stock to sell.

loans.name: Marta

texts.es:
La señora Marta es separada desde hace 12 años, vive en la ciudad de Curuguaty, ella es comerciante, tiene una Despensa y Carnicería, los cuales son muy conocidos en el barrio.
Comenta que empezó su comercio con la venta de un terreno qye tenia, y luego gracias a su trabajo y sacrificio, su despensa fue creciendo y luego ya su negocio se mantenía solo gracias a las ganancias que tenía. Ella se define como una persona muy trabajadora y con muchas ganas de salir adelante e ir superándose a sí misma.
Marta solicita el crédito para poder abastecer su despensa con panificados, fideos, gaseosas, arroz y demás insumos, que son los que más salidas tiene. Con estos productos podrá cumplir con la demanda que tiene y también ir mejorando sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Marta, who separated from her partner 12 years ago, lives in the city of Curuguaty and is a shopkeeper. She owns a grocery store and a butcher’s, which are very well known in the neighborhood. She mentions that she started her business with the sale of land she owned, and then thanks to her work and sacrifice, her grocery store grew and her business is now self-sufficient using only the profits it returns. Marta defines herself as a very hard-working person and someone who is very keen to get ahead and to better herself. 

Marta is asking for this loan to stock her store with baked goods, noodles, fizzy drinks, rice and other supplies, which are the products that generate the biggest profits. With these products, she will be able to meet demand as well as improve her income.

loans.use: to buy baked goods, noodles, fizzy drinks, rice and other supplies.

loans.name: Toquilleras  (Sigsig) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Las Toquilleras está formado por 9 socias y 2 socios, quienes viven por el cantón del Sigsig que esta ubicado en la parte centro oriental de la provincia del Azuay, su clima es propicio para la plantación de manzanas y varias frutas, su gente se dedica a la elaboración de sombreros de paja toquilla muy conocidos en el mundo, se dedican a la cría de animales, agricultura, mantienen su cultura y tradiciones como nuestras socias quienes laboran en diferentes actividades económicas las mismas que les permiten ayudar y solventar los gastos de sus hogares, se caracterizan por ser personas muy amables, gentiles y de un corazón muy cálido. 

Una de las socias de este grupo es la Señora. Hortencia, tiene 40 años, es casada y fruto de su unión conyugal ha concebido 4 hijos de 19, 16, 14 y 12 años de edad, sus tres primeros hijos están estudiando en el colegio y su último hijo está en una escuelita de la localidad. Su esposo labora como jardinero, la casa en la que viven es de su propiedad.

La Señora Hortencia hace 20 años se dedica a la elaboración de sombreros de paja toquilla actividad que la aprendió de sus padres, como pasa en casa también cría animales como son cuyes, ovejas y cerdos.
 
Este es su primer crédito su crédito que realiza en el banco comunal al cual fue invitada por sus amigas y vecinas, su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de pollos.

Su meta es tener una tienda en su casa.

La foto pequeña es de una socio que no pudo estar presente cuando se tomó la foto del grupo.
texts.en:
The communal bank Las Torquilleras  is composed of 9 female and 2 male members.   They live in the canton of Sigsig which is located in the east-central part of the province of Azuay.  The climate there is good to plant apples and other fruits, and the people work making the world-renowned straw hats from toquilla (the straw used in Panama hats).  They also work in animal husbandry and agriculture and they maintain their culture and traditions.  Like others in the province, these members work in various economic activities that permit them to pay their household expenses.  They are friendly people, kind and with very warm hearts.

One of the members of the group is Hortencia.  She is 40 years old, is married and through her conjugal union has conceived four children of 19, 16, 14, and 12 years of age.  Her first three children are studying in high school and her last child is in a small school in her town.  Her husband works as a gardener.  The house in which they live is their property.

For 20 years Hortencia has worked in making hats from toquilla straw, an activity that she learned from her parents as it was done in her house.  She also raises animals such as guinea pigs, sheep, and pigs.

This is her first loan.  The loan is made through the communal bank that she was invited to join by her friends and neighbors.  She is going to invest her loan in the purchase of chickens.

Her goal is to have a store in her house.

The small photo is of a member who could not be present when the group photo was taken.

loans.use: to buy chickens.

loans.name: Las Educadoras Group

texts.es:
Las Educadoras, son un grupo formado por mujeres emprendedoras del municipio de Ciénega de Flores. Se conocen porque son vecinas y comerciantes. Esto último fue el motivo para reunirse y tomar el compromiso de crédito grupal para invertir en sus negocios y hacerlos crecer.
Blanca Nohemi, es mujer, esposa y madre de dos hijos. Ella pensando en apoyar en el hogar, sin descuidar la calidad de educación y cuidado de sus hijos, decidió establecer una estética en su hogar, donde atiende a personas de todas las edades para corte de cabello. Empezó empíricamente, pero con el tiempo a aprendido el arte de la belleza.
Ella solicita este crédito para crecer sus negocio comprando mercancía que le permita ofrecer nuevos servicios, así como renovar el equipo que actualmente utiliza (tijeras, secadora y maquina para cortar cabello).
texts.en:
“Las Educadoras” (The Educators) is a group formed by enterprising women from the municipality of Ciénega de Flores.  They know each other because they are neighbors and merchants.  This was the motivation for them to join together and take on the commitment of a group loan to invest in their businesses and make them grow.

Blanca Nohemí is a wife and the mother of two children.  Intending to help support the home without neglecting her children’s care and education, she decided to establish a home-based beauty salon where she offers haircuts to people of all ages.  She started empirically and in time has learned the art of beauty services.

She’s asking for this loan to grow her business buying merchandise that will make it possible for her to offer new services as well as to upgrade the equipment she currently uses (scissors, dryer and hair clipper).

loans.use: to upgrade equipment and buy merchandise for the salon.

loans.name: Cerelyn

texts.en:
Cerelyn is from Pantaon, Ozamis City. She is 28 years old.  Cerelyn is married and has a child. 

To make a living, Cerelyn runs a general store, selling a variety of food and home used products in the local community. Cerelyn has been in her business for three years and earns 5,000 a month for these activities.

Cerelyn is requesting a loan of 8,000 which will be used to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps etc. In 2011, Cerelyn joined GDMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps etc.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to purchase more fish to sell for her fish vending business.

Concepcion has been in this business for two years. Concepcion earns more income from her general store.

Concepcion has sustained her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Tsitsino

texts.en:
Tsitsino is 54 years old. She lives in a small village of Sachkhere District with her son, Arsen.  Arsen is employed in Tbilisi (capital city of the country) as a worker. 

Tsitsino leads the agricultural business for the family. In particular, she has two milk cows.  Tsitsino produces traditional Georgian cheese and sells it to local dairy products retailers.  Along with the dairy farm, she grows haricot and maize on family owned (0.4 hectare) land.  Harvested products are sold to local retailers as well.  The total average monthly income of the family is 1000 Laris.

Tsitsino requested credit to open a grocery store in a building located in her garden.  Tsitsino will purchase fridges and grocery products for resale. According to her estimate, the store will be profitable, as there are no similar stores nearby in the village.  She will offer to customers a big assortment of products.  Tsitsino plans to reinvest the profit during the first year to expand the store.

loans.use: to purchase fridge and grocery products for resale.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn works hard to support her family.  She is married and has a bakery business in the Philippines.

Evelyn requested a PHP 30000 loan through NWTF to purchase more ingredients for her bakery.

Evelyn has been in this business for 24 years.

In the future, Evelyn would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients for her bakery.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma works hard to support one child. She is married and buys and sells ready to wear clothing in the Philippines.

Gemma requested a PHP 4100 loan through NWTF to buy of solar lamp.

She is getting the lamp because she wants to have backup lighting in case of emergency.

Gemma is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to buy of solar lamp.

loans.name: Buscando El Exito  (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Buscando el Éxito está formado por 12 socias que viven por diferentes lugares de la ciudad de Cuenca, ciudad de clima frió, es la tercera ciudad de mayor importancia económica del país, desde Diciembre de 1999 es Patrimonio Cultural de la Humanidad y tiene muchos lugares para visitar, su gente se es de un corazón cálido y mantienen la cultura y tradiciones de sus pueblos. Las socias son mujeres luchadoras que viven el día a día en sus trabajos, realizándolos de la mejor manera para salir adelante y brindarles a sus familias una mejor calidad de vida. 

Una de las socias de este grupo es la Señora Natividad, tiene 57 años, es viuda y en su unión conyugal ha concebido 5 hijos quienes ya son todos mayores de edad, casados y viven independientes. La casa en la que vive es de su propiedad.

La Señora. Natividad hace 3 años se dedica a la venta de varios productos como: ropa y cosméticos de marca, labora recorriendo de lunes a viernes sin un horario fijo. También fabrica chales para la venta.

Este es su primer crédito que realiza en el banco comunal y lo va a invertir en la compra de lana para la elaboración de sus chales, cosméticos y ropa  para tener una mayor variedad de productos para su clientela.
 
Su sueño es viajar a los Estados Unidos. 

La foto pequeña es de una socia que no pudo estar presente cuando se tomó la foto del grupo.
texts.en:
The “Buscando el Éxito” (Seeking Success) communal bank is composed of 12 members who live in different parts of the city of Cuenca, a city with a cold climate that’s the country’s third most important economically.  Since December, 1999, it’s been a Cultural Heritage of Humanity and it has many places to visit.  Its residents are warmhearted and they preserve the culture and traditions of its peoples.  The members are tenacious women who live day to day in their work doing it the best way possible to get ahead and provide their families with better quality of life.

One of the members of this group is Natividad, 57.  She’s a widow and has five children who are all now married adults living on their own.  The house she lives in is her property.

Natividad has been selling various products like clothes and brand name cosmetics for three years.  She works going from place to place Monday through Friday with no fixed schedule.  She also makes shawls to sell.

This is the first loan she’s taken in the communal bank and she will use it to buy yarn to make the shawls, cosmetics and clothes to have a larger variety of products to offer her customers.  Her dream is to visit the United States.

The small photo is of one of the members who was unable to be present when the group photo was taken.

loans.use: to buy yarn, cosmetics and clothes.

loans.name: Sabah

texts.en:
Sabah is a 57-year-old Lebanese married woman living with her husband and only one working child. They’re all united and cooperative. She started to work as a tailor from her home in 1993 after having many years of experience in this domain. As for her husband, he has been working as a carpenter since 2005. 

Today, she’s requesting to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase added tailoring tools that will allow her to increase her clothes production. In the future, she plans to open her own tailoring shop.

loans.use: to purchase more tailoring tools.

loans.name: Zurab

texts.en:
Zurab is 33 years old. He lives in the Kareli District with his mother, Tamar. Their only source of the income is agriculture. Zurab and Tamar spend most of their time farming. They work hard, especially in the spring to complete seasonal works properly. The family also owns two milk cows and five pigs. They sell on average 40 piglets and 30 kg of home-made cheese to local retailers.  They grow tomatoes, cabbage and beets on 3.3 hectare of family land. They sell harvested vegetables to local retailers as well. Total average monthly income of the family is 700 Laris. 

Zurab requested credit to finance seasonal agricultural works. In particular, he will rent a tractor to til the land, purchase fertilizers and vegetables’ seeds and feed for pigs.  Zurab and Tamar will hope that the weather conditions are favorable to help yield a good harvest. Income will pay for their daily expenses.

loans.use: to rent a tractor, purchase fertilizers, seeds and feed for pigs.

loans.name: Ma. Gina

texts.en:
Ma. Gina is from Tabid, Ozamis City. She is 38 years old, married, and has a child.  She harvests and sells ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been in her business for 8 years and earns 2,000 a month. 

In 2010, Ma. Gina joined GDMPC.  She is requesting a loan of 3,000 to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets.

loans.name: Mayra Viviana

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, ciudad hermosa de verdes  montañas y paisajes  encantadores, conocida desde hace muchos años como la Ciudad Del Valle  encontramos el lugar donde se reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal La Frontera De Urvavisa.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Mayra, tiene 31 años de edad, está divorciada pero de esa relación  tuvo un hijo el cual tiene 12 años, actualmente mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene otro niño de 4 años de edad, el mayor estudia en colegio. Su marido es comerciante.

Ella después del divorcio tuvo que ver cómo le daba lo necesario a su hijo es así que con lo que tenia compro una copiadora y puso un pequeño local en el centro de la ciudad, donde dia a dia se dedica a sacar copias, su puesto lo tiene cerca del juzgado de la ciudad por lo cual hasta su copiadora acuden  muchas personas que necesitan realizar alguna actividad en dicho lugar, además de esto también y con la ayuda de una hermana se dedican a la venta de ropa interior y zapatillas, ventas que las realiza puerta  a puerta y es su hermana le ayuda cuando ella está muy ocupada, lleva más de 5 años en su negocio y le va muy bien.

Este crédito lo va a emplear para comprar ropa interior, zapatillas y hojas de papel. Esta desde el inicio en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda y beneficios que recibe del banco.

Su sueño es tener un gran centro de copiado con local propio.

La señora estaba con conjuntivitis por eso en la foto esta con gafas.
texts.en:
In the city of Portoviejo, beautiful city of green mountains and enchanting vistas, known for many years as “Ciudad Del Valle” (City of the Valley), we found the place where every fifteen days the members of the “La Frontera de Urvavisa” communal bank meet.

We met Mayra, 31, here.  She’s divorced but has a 12 year old son from that relationship.  She’s currently in a common law relationship from which she has another little boy who is four years old.  The older one attends school and her husband’s a merchant.

After her divorce she had to find a way to provide what was needed for her son so she used what she had to buy a copier and set up a small locale downtown where every day she works making copies.  Her stand is near the municipal courthouse so many people who need to transact affairs there come to her stand to make copies.  In addition to this and with help from her sister she sells underwear and slippers door to door and her sister helps her when she’s very busy.  She’s been in business more than five years and does very well.

She will use the loan to buy underwear, slippers and sheets of paper.  She’s been in the communal bank since its founding and she likes it because of the support and benefits she gets from the bank.  Her dream is to have a large copying center in her own locale.

She had conjunctivitis which is why she appears in the photo wearing sunglasses.

loans.use: to buy underwear, slippers and sheets of paper.

loans.name: Angela Ramona

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, ciudad hermosa de verdes  montañas y paisajes  encantadores, conocida desde hace muchos años como la Ciudad Del Valle  encontramos el lugar donde se reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal La Frontera De Urvavisa.

La señora  Angela es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que le brindan los créditos para salir adelante en su negocio y mejorar su situación económica. Tiene 57 años de edad, hace varios años su esposo falleció pero de  esa relación tiene tres hijos los cuales ya son mayores de edad e independientes.

Ella para salir adelante junto a su familia, tiene una tienda general en su casa, allí vende todo tipo de productos como: arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, legumbres, verduras y carne, trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, ella también vende ropa y zapatos, ventas que realiza en su tienda o en ciertas ocasiones también las realiza puerta a puerta, nos cuenta que a ella le encanta estar en su negocio ya que allí además de ganarse la vida se entretiene y se entera de las novedades que pasan a su alrededor. Tiene más de 15 años con su negocio y le va muy bien.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, ropa, zapatos y otros productos de primera necesidad.
 
Sus metas son seguir adelante en su negocio y que su tienda crezca cada día más.
texts.en:
In the city of Portoviejo, beautiful city of green mountains and enchanting vistas, known for many years as “Ciudad Del Valle” (City of the Valley), we found the place where every fifteen days the members of the “La Frontera de Urvavisa” communal bank meet.

Ángela is a founding member of the communal bank and she likes it because of the help the loans provide to get ahead in her business and improve her economic situation.  She’s 57 years old and her husband died several years ago but she has three children who are all now independent adults.

To get ahead with her family, she has a general store at home.  She sells all types of products like rice, sugar, oil, detergent, vegetables, greens and meat there.  She works every day from 6am until 8pm and sometimes even later.

She also sells clothes and shoes in her store and sometimes door to door.  She tells us that she loves being in her store because besides earning a livelihood she keeps herself busy and keeps abreast of everything going on around her.  She’s been in business more than 15 years and she does very well.

She will use the loan to better stock her store.  She is going to buy rice, sugar, oil, clothes, shoes and other basic staple items.  Her goals are to continue in business and that the store grows more every day.

loans.use: to buy basic staples to stock her store.

loans.name: Maria Concepcion

texts.es: Maria, habitante del departamento de León es originaria de Villa Nueva Chinandega tiene 52 años de edad,  realizo estudios hasta el sexto grado de primaria, de oficio comerciante en el negocio de pulpería, madre de 7 hijos de los cuales solo uno está a su cargo los otros son mayores de edad de vida independiente. Inicio su actividad por medio de la ayuda de un hijo que le dio dinero para que hiciera compras y se quedara en la casa ayudándose así puso su negocio lo que actualmente es su pulpería donde recibe el apoyo del esposo y su hija menor. También cuenta con otros ingresos  pues el esposo y algunos de sus hijos le dan remesas para los gastos del hogar, sus productos los comercializa en su misma comunidad ya que donde esta se encuentra satisfecha pues tiene  buena clientela que la visitan a diario. Solicita el préstamo para comprar granos básicos gaseosa, huevo, jabón, pan, jugos y leche   todo lo necesario para el negocio el cual estima le ayudara ya que podrá surtir el negocio con productos que le generaran más ganancias, sus planes futuros es llegar a tener un negocio grande bien surtido con todos los productos para satisfacer cada una de las necesidades de los clientes.
texts.en: María, resident of the department of León, is originally from Villa Nueva Chinandega.  She is 52 years old and she has a sixth grade education.  She is the shopkeeper of a small grocery store for a living and she is the mother of seven children, of whom only one is her dependent, as the others are adults who are on their own.  She started her business with the help of one of her sons, who gave her money so that she could buy things and stay at home to help herself out.  That is how she set up her business, which is now her grocery store, where she is helped out by her husband and youngest daughter.  She also depends on other sources of income, as her husband and some of her children give her money for her household expenses.  She sells her products in her own community, as she is happy where she is and she has a good clientele who visit her daily.  She is asking for this loan to buy staple grains, soft drinks, eggs, soap, bread, juice, and milk, all of which are needed for her business and which she hopes will help her, as she will be able to stock her business with the products that earn her the most money.  Her plans for the future are to have a big business that is well stocked with all the products to satisfy every one of her customers' needs.

loans.use: to buy staple grains, soft drinks, eggs, soap, bread, juice, and milk

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma works hard to support 4 children. She is married and buys and sells livestock to earn a living, in the Philippines.

Wilma requested a PHP 4100 loan through NWTF to purchase of solar lamp.

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to save money by minimizing her kerosene expenses.

Wilma is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase of solar lamp.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a married woman who has four children.  She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

She sells coconuts at the market and Mwanasha has been in business for two years. Her primary customers are her local residents. Her major challenge is seasonality, and food is her greatest monthly expense.

With the Ksh 15000 loan, she will be able to purchase more coconuts for sell.

loans.use: to purchase more coconuts for sell.

loans.name: Mohamad Fayez

texts.en:
Mohamad Fayez is a 48 year-old widowed father of four children.  He is a hard working man who sacrifices his life for his children's happiness and living.

Mohamad Fayez has been a furniture maker since 1993.  His special talent is painting furniture and he is well known in the region.

Mohamad Fayez  is applying for a loan from KIVA partner Al Majmoua, to buy necessary business products such as paints and furniture coloring materials.

This is Mohamad Fayez's second experience with Al Majmoua, his previous loan helped him improve his business, and he is very optimistic about this loan.

loans.use: to buy necessary business products such as paints and furniture coloring materials.

loans.name: Racar Bajo  (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Racar Bajo está formado por 5 socias y 3 socios quienes viven por la comunidad de Racar en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es de clima frió, se caracteriza por tener una gran riqueza natural y arquitectónica, es desde Diciembre de 1999 Patrimonio Cultura de la Humanidad, su gente es de un corazón cálido, amable, gentil y mantienen la cultura y tradiciones de sus pueblos. 
Nuestras socias y socios en su mayor parte se dedican a laborar en el trabajo que sus padres les han enseñado siguiendo la tradición de elaboración de ladrillos, cría de animales y a la agricultura.

Una de las socias de este grupo es la Señorita. Mayra, tiene 20 años de edad, es soltera y vive en casa de sus padres, su padre trabaja en el extranjero y su mamá tiene una fábrica de ladrillos.
 
La Señorita. Mayra trabaja en un taller de costura de lunes a viernes desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 6 de la tarde, esta actividad la realiza hace un año.  Los fines de semana estudia en una academia de belleza.

Es socia del banco comunal hace un año y medio, su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de materiales para su estudio como maquinas para cortar el cabello, tijeras, tintes y otros productos.
 
Su meta es culminar sus estudios y llegar a ser profesional.
texts.en:
The Racar Bajo Communal Bank is comprised of five female and three male members who live in the community of Racar, in the city of Cuenca.  This city, known for its cold climate, abundant natural resources, and architecture, was named a UNESCO World Heritage Site in December of 1999.  The inhabitants are warm-hearted, friendly, and courteous people who maintain the culture and traditions of their towns.  Most of the members work in the trades taught to them by their parents, and carry on the traditions of making bricks, animal husbandry, and agriculture.

One of the members of this group is Mayra.  She is 20 years old, unmarried, and lives with her parents.  Her father works outside of the country and her mother has a brick factory.  Mayra works in a sewing workshop from Monday to Friday from 8:00 in the morning until 6:00 in the evening.  She has held this job for one year.  On the weekends, she studies at a beauty academy.  

She has been a member of the communal bank for one and a half years.  She plans to invest the new loan in the purchase of items for her studies such as hair cutting implements, scissors, dyes, and other products.  Her goal is to complete her studies and become a professional hair stylist.

loans.use: to purchase hair cutting implements, scissors, dyes, and other items for her studies.

loans.name: Akimu

texts.en:
Akimu is a 27 year old married man with two children who are not yet enrolled in school.  He lives in his own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.  

He sells coconuts and has been in this business for the last three years.  Akimu describes market competition as his major challenge.  He aspires to hire employees in future.

He plans to use the loan of Ksh 50000 to purchase more coconuts for resell.  He joined Yehu because of their good products.

loans.use: to purchase more coconuts for resell.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 37 year-old married man and father of one child. 

Ali has been a butcher since 1999; his business is going on fine.  His good reputation and quality of products he serves helps him development business.

Ali has been an Al Majmoua borrower for six cycles.  All his previous loans helped him improve his business and his family's social and financial situations.

Ali is applying for a loan from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, to increase his meat capital with special prices since he will pay in cash. These special prices help him sell his products.  Ali will also increase his herbs stock since he makes special blends and sauces.

He hopes, that in the future he can decorate his butchery in a better way.

loans.use: to increase his meat at better prices.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia es una mujer con 62 años de edad, casada, con 4 hijos, vive con su familia, en una el distrito de Cayalti provincia de Chiclayo, y cuenta con los servicios básicos de agua, desagüe y luz.
  Julia cuenta con un statio wagon  que se dedica al servicio de transporte público y cubre la ruta de los caseríos Cayalti- Zaña y viceversa, desde hace más de 8 años.
El monto solicitado del préstamo es de 4,500 nuevos soles lo solicita el  préstamo para el mantenimiento y compra de SOAT de su vehiculo y  de esta manera obtener ingresos y  poder mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Julia, 62, is married and has four children.  She lives with her family in Cayalti District, Chiclayo Province.  She has basic utilities: water, sewage and electricity.

Julia has a station wagon that she uses to provide transportation services on the Cayalti-Zaña route; she’s been in business more than 8 years.

She’s asking for a 4500 new sol loan to service the vehicle and purchase SOAT (required accident insurance policy) for her vehicle in order to obtain more income and be able to improve her quality of life.

loans.use: to service his vehicle and buy insurance.

loans.name: Yawah

texts.en: Yawah is 43 years old and lives in Airport Community. She is married and has six children between the ages of 6 and 29. Three of them are presently in school and live at home, while the oldest one is working. Since 2004, she has been selling peppers, beans, peanuts, sugar, and flour. She makes more profit and has more customers. She is requesting a loan to purchase more peppers, beans, peanuts, sugar, and flour for her business. Her plan is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more peppers, beans, peanuts, sugar, and flour for her business

loans.name: Nicolàs

texts.es:
Nicolás es un hombre de 47  años de edad, Casado, con 2  hijos dependientes, Vive en casa propia, contando con los servicios de  luz y agua, el lugar es una comunidad pequeña con un aproximado de 200  familias; actualmente vive en el caserío Valle Nuevo distrito de Mochumì, ubicado a 15 minutos de esta.
La actividad que desarrolla Nicolás es la comercialización de animales lo cual tiene bastante experiencia en este tipo de negocio; así, mismo comercializa carne de cerdo al kilaje. , el negocio esta situado en su domicilio, aprendió esta actividad de sus padres, es decir conoce a la perfección el rubro.   , y 
El monto solicitado del crédito es de 4,500 nuevos soles lo que será para invertir en compra animales como porcinos, caprinos, ovinos, aves de corral, etc., y de está manera poder aumentar su capital de trabajo y poder tener mejores ingresos para su hogar, así mismo cuenta con clientes ya establecidos.
texts.en:
Nicolás is a 47-year-old gentleman who is married and has two dependent children. He lives in his own home which receives electricity and running water. Nicolás currently lives in the village of Valle Nuevo, which is 15 minutes away from the District of Mochumi. This place is a small community that has approximately 200 families.

Nicolás has a business in which he sells animals. He has plenty of experience in this type of work. Nicolas also sells pork based on the weight. His business is located at his home and he learned this trade from his parents. Nicolás is known for being a perfectionist at his work. The loan amount of 4,500 PEN that he is requesting will be invested in the purchase of pigs, goats, sheep, poultry, and other livestock. This will enable him to increase his operating capital so that he can earn more household income. Nicolás already has established customers.

loans.use: to buy small animals.

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en: Josefa is 53 years old and married with two children. She lives in Capucao, Ozamiz City. Josefa used her last loan to purchase crop fertilizer such as manure. Her business is successful, and she's taking a new loan to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. In the future, she hopes to be able to grow her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Catalina  Del Carmen

texts.es:
Catalina de 38 años de edad es originaria de Chinandega actualmente vive en Granada, casada, madre de tres hijos los cuales están a su cargo, de oficio comerciante en el negocio de pulpería, realizo estudio  hasta la primaria. Inicio su actividad desde hace 2 años después de haber tenido una mala experiencia en su primer matrimonio queda como madre soltera decide viajar a Costa Rica en busca de una mejor vida para ella y para sus hijos trabajo por un tiempo como empleada de una familia, luego dejo el trabajo comenzó a vender buñuelos y fritanga de ese trabajo fue ahorrando dinero que utilizo para regresar a Nicaragua a poner su propio negocio dejando en Costa Rica a su actual esposo que conoció porque trabajaba con ella  luego ella se regreso a Nicaragua. Catalina poco tiempo después de haber puesto su negocio vio la necesidad de inyectarle más en productos debido a la alta demanda de la clientela. Ella realizo préstamos en instituciones financieras para conseguir capital de trabajo. Actualmente  lleva dos años en el negocio de pulpería donde recibe el apoyo de su esposo y de sus hijos.
Cuenta con otros ingresos ya que el esposo viaja a Costa Rica en temporadas buenas de trabajo para mandarle remesas que invierte en la pulpería. Catalina realiza el préstamo para compra de granos básicos tales como pan, galletas, leche, aceite, azúcar y compra de bebidas variadas el cual estima le ayudara ya que podrá satisfacer a la clientela con los productos de mayor demanda y ampliara su negocio.
texts.en:
Catalina, 38, is from Chinandega but currently lives in Granada.  She’s married and the mother of three children who are still in her care.  She’s a merchant; she has a grocery store.  She completed elementary school.

She started her business two years ago after having a bad experience with he first marriage.  She was left a single mother so she decided to go to Costa Rica in search of a better life for her and her children. She worked for a time with a family as a domestic employee.  She left that job and started selling ‘buñuelos’ [fried flour tortilla sprinkled with sugar and cinnamon] and fried fast food and saved some of what she earned from that business to return to Nicaragua and open her own business.  She left her current husband in Costa Rica because she met him there because they worked together.  She returned to Nicaragua.

Shortly after opening her business, Catalina saw the need of injecting more products into it due to high customer demand.  She took out loans in financial institutions in order to get working capital.  She’s now been in the grocery store business for two years and she gets support from her husband and her children.

She also gets additional income because her husband travels to Costa Rica during good work seasons and sends her stipends that she invests in the grocery store.

Catalina is taking out the loan to buy basic staple items like bread, cookies, milk, oil, sugar and to buy assorted soft-drinks that she feels will help her satisfy customer demand with products in highest demand and will expand the business.

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Erkhembaatar

texts.en:
Erkhembaatar, 26, is a taxi driver. He lives with his mother, sisters and brothers in one small, old house which is located in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.
